label: Build/Dependency
llm_input_text:
Title: Update test suite to include Rails 3.0.7

Description:
N/A

Discussion:
+1 for Rails 3.1 support :-)
---
Getting incompatible gem version messages when running bundler update on a rails 3.1 project, which I'm assuming you're aware of: How soon before support for 3.1 might be available?
---
I'm not getting any gem incompatibility issues here. Instead, I find that bundler is just hanging on me... My Gemfile: $ bundle install Any ideas?
---
Its done that to me as well. I've often ctrl-c canceled it and retried, resulting in the messages I mentioned above.
---
I was having major issues connecting to rubygems.org and GitHub today… Were you having this problem yesterday? Also, try updating rubygems.
---
The solution for the bundler issue (for this) is to specify that you want the git version of meta_search in your Gemfile Previous versions of meta_search were using pessimistic versions (~> 3.0.1) in a strange way (should only be ~> 3.0) and this sent bundler into an infinite loop. What should have happened was it should have FAILED with the current published version of meta_search and rails 3.1 beta. So use the latest meta search and everything gets resolved.
---
Thanks jeffrafter. How did you track that down?

label: Logic/Workflow
llm_input_text:
Title: ActiveAdmin.default_sort_order "id_desc" prevents use of scopes with joins

Description:
Hi, I'm using a model with some scopes involving joins. For example: If I add this scope to my ActiveAdmin config, I get the following error when viewing the Users index: This appears to be because in [ lib/active_admin.rb ](https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/blob/master/lib/active_admin.rb#L51) the default sort order is set to "id_desc", which doesn't then get scoped with the appropriate table name - hence the ambiguous query error. There's a gist [here](https://gist.github.com/972217) with the full stack trace in case it's useful... Cheers, Simon p.s. thanks for a wonderful tool, by the way - I'm really loving what I've seen of it so far.

label: Dev/Test
llm_input_text:
Title: comments vs admin_notes config option

Description:
It looks like the project was recently updated to rename admin_notes to comments. However, the config option still seems to indicate that the option name (for enabling/disabling comments) is 'admin_notes'. If you choose to disable admin_notes right now in the initializer (as shown below), it'll break, as ShowPageHelper is looking for active_admin_config.comments? rather than active_admin_config.admin_notes? I fixed this in our fork by reverting to the admin_notes option that's already available. However, I assume the right thing to do is to update the rest of the project to use 'comments'. Didn't want to make that change without discussing it first though, as I wasn't sure what the intentions were. And I also seem to have failures on the master branch atm (on both Rails 3.0.7 and 3.1.0 edge). https://github.com/wantful/active_admin/commit/78e8778949a1407d48293afe9d9ccb396fffa65d

For example, in the demo, when you show a customer, the customer details if long enough and do not break (e.g. an email address) will overflow outside the sidebar. Image: http://i.imgur.com/wzHEr.png Link: http://demo.activeadmin.info/admin/customers/617 Can fix with something like: I can submit a patch later if that's desired, but I'm not very familiar with SASS.

Good catch. Thanks. No worries about the patch I'll get this merged in.

label: UI/Responsive
llm_input_text:
Title: Dropdown menus float all the way to the left in Firefox

Description:
Happens with Firefox 4.0 Mac, and my client says it happens in Firefox on Windows too. Screenshot: http://cl.ly/3F0h0t3M3s422i0X2L0d ![Screenshot](http://f.cl.ly/items/1X3K3v0r1x2h181F3D3O/Screen%20shot%202011-05-26%20at%2011.03.08%20PM.png) I'll try to tinker around and fix it, unless someone beats me to it. :)

Discussion:
I confirm this issue also occurs in Firefox 4.0 under Linux
---
Uh oh, will take a look at this as soon as possible. Unless of course you would like to patch it :-)
---
I have to go out of town but if you don't get around to it by Sunday I will jump in and get my hands dirty :)
---
Figured it out, it's because the top level LIs are "display: inline", and FF doesn't like this. Changing to "inline-block" should fix 'er. Will do when I have a chance
---
Ah, very cool. I'll try to figure out something else to work on then :)

Description:
I get the following error when I have nil/null values in the column where I call status_tag in my index table view: My thoughts are it should return a css class called .null or .nil rather than not an error. Something like: I have managed to work around this in my index table view by using:

Thanks for the report. I've added this as a fix for next release On 2011-05-30, at 6:47 PM, MeetDomreply@reply.github.com wrote: > I get the following error when I have nil/null values in the column I call status_tag in my index table view: > > undefined method `downcase' for nil:NilClass > > My thoughts are it should return a css class called .null or .nil rather than not an error. Something like: > > Null > > I have managed to work around this in my index table view by using: > > column("State") { |order| status_tag(order.state || "New") } > > ## > > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub: > https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/issues/131
---
I'm working on it. So: `status_tag(nil)` should return: 1. `" "` 2. `" None "` 3. `" Null "` 4. `""` 5. `nil` ? I'm for 1.

I would say 1 as well

Hmmm, I would have to go with 1 as well I think, that makes sense. Thanks for asking.

+1 for number 1

label: Logic/Workflow
llm_input_text:
Title: Update Action doesn't work for STI models

Description:
When you edit a model that implements single-table inheritance, the updates are not saved

Discussion:
Thanks. We should definitely add STI models to the test suite to make sure we have everything working correctly.
---
@tkleft We implemented some cukes to test STI and they all seem to pass. Could you please post the stacktrace and relevant code of the issue you had?
---
I actually don't get an error....everything goes well, but the object is never updated. I patched the update_resource action to do this to fix the problem: controller do def update_resource(object, attributes) object.attributes = params[object.class.to_s.underscore] end Perhaps it could be fixed upstream too by passing the correct attributes into the function. Are you able to repro this on your end? On May 25, 2011, at 7:56 PM, gregbell wrote: > @tkleft We implemented some cukes to test STI and they all seem to pass. Could you please post the stacktrace and relevant code of the issue you had? > > ## > > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub: > https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/issues/52#comment_1239853
---
Ah...just looked at your cuke. I think it doesn't cover the case I was using. Let me put what I was trying to accomplish in terms of your models: User and Publisher. I only have "User" registered with ActiveAdmin, not "Publisher," and I was trying to update a "Publisher" by going to /admin/users/:id/edit, and then save the form. Does that make sense?
---
say you have the models ActiveAdmin.register Category when you update an instance of ArticleCategory the form sends an article_category => { :name => "test" } where active_admin expects category => { :name => "test" }. you can fix this by adding :as => :category to the form.

label: Data/Format
llm_input_text:
Title: Images referenced incorrectly (Rails 3.1 w/ asset pipeline)

Description:
The active_admin stylesheets reference images from css with a simple url('/images/...') expression, but that is not where the images are when using the asset pipeline. Presumably in production this would double-fail because of the sprockets-computed hash-keyed name for the asset. I messed around with renaming _base and _header to have an erb suffix and using image_path, but I wasn't able to get it to work. Not sure if that's to do with how sprockets works with rails engines or just how the sass compiles (I'm not very familiar with sass). I was able to work around this in my rails app without copying the images into public by just overriding the background-image properties in app/assets/stylesheets/active_admin.css.scss.erb: https://gist.github.com/1059513

Discussion:
Yeah this is an issue for us. This is definitely something we have to deal with before releasing this version.
---
Working well for me. Thanks.

label: Dev/Test
llm_input_text:
Title: Logout link missing :method => 'delete'

Description:
The logout link, https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/blob/master/lib/active_admin/views/header_renderer.rb#L30, is missing the :method parameter so a user gets a routing error for '/admin/logout'.

Discussion:
I get this too - is there an easy fix?
---
I thought I fixed it here https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/pull/249 and I swear I had it work once or twice in a sample application but when I tested it in my application, it still didn't work. Also, I realized I should've updated the specs to prove it worked. I'm going to keep working on it.
---
I think the issue is that active admin isn't loading the jquery rails file (called active_admin_vendor.js in active admin) which is what actually makes the :method => :delete work. I forked activeadmin to fix this thinking there wasn't much development going on anymore before I realized that there were some really recent commits on the project. Here is the commit that fixed it for me: https://github.com/oponder/active_admin/commit/44d89e7180d4d657ddc57c93a7582f36c11042a4
---
Thanks @opondor, that explains it. I must've tested my fix in my real application when I still had jquery-rails installed (which I later removed). I'll see if I can't find some time to create a clean fork using your commit and write a test for it too some time soon.
---
While we wait to a proper fix to the problem I have this patch for /config/routes.rb In this way we don't need to mess around with fork and so on...
---
Thanks @libo ...

label: Dev/Test
llm_input_text:
Title: nested resource update action && no dashboard without namespace

Description:
i encountered issue with nested resource while having After submiting the edit form for Image active_admin tries to redirect me to **article_image_path** instead of **admin_article_image_path** i needed to continue development so i tried to set no namespace and this works fine, however now i do not get my dashboard loaded properly (active_admin master branch, rails 3.0.8)

Discussion:
Also, with everything default except for you generate wrong logout path in the layout **/false/logout** instead of **/admin_users/logout** and the logout path is generated as **/false** instead of just **/**
---
I had a same problem about the config.default_namespace = false with rails 3.0.3.
---
I've been wrestling with namespaces for weeks. You might want to try :root instead of false, but there are still issues. I think it just hasn't really been tested as of yet.
---
I'm having the same issues here using config.default_namespace = false. None of the Devise routes work anymore, in fact I end up in an endless loop error: Too many redirects occurred trying to open... Dashboard doesn't work no matter where you put it, what you call it, or what routes you create. Is there an estimated timeframe on milestone 0.3.0? I'm trying to decide if I need the lack of namespace enough to fix it myself because I want to roll this app out by weeks end.
---
Personally I have had to abandon all immediate hopes of using this gem in anything other than the /admin namespace, and regret it took me so long to make that decision. I've spent many hours trying to get around limitations only to bump up against another every time. It's also hard to justify the risk of time given that the master branch might diverge even further from what I might expect. The architecture of this gem is quite clever and I like a lot about it, including the arbre library (which I would love to see extracted for use externally). But, as an example, I think the choice to use a DSL to generate an application layout assumes a very narrow use-case, diverges too far from the Rails Way and makes it very difficult (or at least non-DRY) to integrate into, at least, my projects and leverage a consistent user experience. The master branch focus has some basic assumptions that don't yet allow for as much flexibility as my projects require, and I think there are still some critically hooks as well. I do expect that to improve, but, the layout issue still troubles me a lot and prevents me from confidently embracing it as a key component of my apps. So, I assume the present goals of the project are for it to be a sidelined admin interface. Best use is to not fight the defaults, and wait for the it to mature.
---
@aceofspades " I think the choice to use a DSL to generate an application layout assumes a very narrow use-case, diverges too far from the Rails Way and makes it very difficult (or at least non-DRY) to integrate into, at least, my projects and leverage a consistent user experience. " I agree... indeed, AA is a nice choice for really simple Apps admin created in a breeze. I'm struggling with it because my project have a lot nested resources... I can't find an elegant solution to handle these case...

Please run "rails generate active_admin:assets" and add the following to your config/intializers/active_admin.rb file: Let me know if these changes work for you.

llm_input_text:
Title: Perf issue with "all" scope

Description:
I was doing some perf testing and found this issue. [activeadmin-demo/admin/products.rb](https://github.com/gregbell/activeadmin-store/blob/demo/app/admin/products.rb) in your activeadmin-demo project: line 3: scope :all, :default => true Adding the "all" scope causes a full table read on the following line: [active_admin/views/components/scopes.rb](https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/blob/master/lib/active_admin/views/components/scopes.rb): line 52: scoping_class.send(scope.scope_method).count The perf here gets really bad after a few thousand records.

label: Build/Dependency
llm_input_text:
Title: Rails 3.0.9 with postgres crashes on show actions.

Description:
I'm using the default settings for active admin. Exception Partial stacktrace The offending code appears to be in `lib/active_admin/comments/views/active_admin_comments.rb` This fixes the error

Discussion:
Hello, thanks for reporting this. The namespace name is stored as a symbol (https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/blob/master/lib/active_admin/namespace.rb#L35) So it looks like passing `where(:namespace => :admin)` generates the SQL `"active_admin_comments"."namespace" = "active_admin_comments"."admin"` instead of `"active_admin_comments"."namespace" = "admin"`. Is that the expected behaviour or a bug in the Postgresql adapter?
---
This was reported before with rails 3.1 and mysql. https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/issues/103 (See the comments) So I believe this is expected behavior.
---
Well, I discover something new in AR today! :)
---
Two years later and this shitty bug show off again in master.
---
I'm facing the same issue, but with sqlite. Using a fresh rails app and and active_admin master branch, I get `SQLite3::SQLException: no such column: active_admin_comments.admin: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM "active_admin_comments" WHERE "active_admin_comments"."namespace" = "active_admin_comments"."admin"` when visiting the comments index action.
---
[This comment](https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/issues/103#issuecomment-1425822) is the topical one. It looks like certain DB adapters have this problem. What's weird, @marcusg, is that the Rails app that AA autobuilds for testing uses SQLite, but isn't running into this problem. That's an issue, because it means I can't reproduce it, so I can't be sure that any given change fixes it. Could you try changing this line?
---
Can you two try out #2310?
---
@Daxter: using your branch from PR https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/pull/2310 fixed the problem for me. Thanks!
---
Cool. Once I get the failing test sorted, I'll merge the changes in.
---
Okay @marcusg, #2310 has been merged into master :]
---
Very nice, @Daxter. Thanks! :+1:

label: Dev/Test
llm_input_text:
Title: undefined method `sign_out_via' for Devise:Module

Description:
This commit b93a930811280d12d40c12afc4832df338c532b7 introduced a bug with older versions of devise that does not implement the sign_out_via method. We should check if devise responds_to `sign_out_via` before adding the sign_out_via config option.

label: Dev/Test

Title: Rails 3.0.9: No route matches {:action=>"show", :controller=>"admin/series"}

Description:
I have a model named "Series" and the menu is trying to use `admin_series_path` to build the link. It should be using `admin_series_index_path` Partial output of rake_routes Partial trace

Discussion:
This was closed earlier without any resolution. https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/issues/89
